David Saff wrote:
> I've lately tended toward declarative sentences where possible in my own 
> work, such as
>
> testPushAddsAnElementToEmptyStack
>   
I do the same. Sometimes I derive all my test classes from a base test 
class that converts the test names from CamelCase to spaces and dumps 
them to a file - the "unit documentation". This approach was strongly 
inspired ("copied") by AgileDox (http://agiledox.sourceforge.net). I add 
the resulting file to the repository, and I use it to compare check-ins 
on a "class feature" basis.

For example, here's some test code from a recent project of mine:

    public class _TestRemoteServer extends _BaseTest {
        public void testManagesErrorsOnHttpPost() throws Exception {...}
        public void testGeneratesTheZipFileForTheUpload() throws 
IOException {...}
    }


And here's a piece of the unit documentation file referencing that class:

    ...
    RemoteServer: manages errors on http post
    RemoteServer: generates the zip file for the upload
    ...

The "unit documentation" idea still has to fully prove itself. Still, I 
find that naming tests based on what the class is supposed to do helps 
me during the TDD "design" process.  It's even more useful later, when I 
have to remember what the code is supposed to do. CamelCase becomes 
quite readable after a while, and certainly more readable than the test 
code itself.

    Paolo Perrotta
    Bologna, Italy
